The southern tip of Stuart can be framed as a tropical monsoon climate (Am) in the vicinity of Seabranch Preserve State Park.Summers (May through October) feature with hot temperatures
column12: and frequent (daily) thundershowers that build in the daytime heat. High temperatures are typically in the upper 80s to low 90s. The city's coastal location prevents temperatures from becoming very hot
column13: though heat indices are often over 100 °F (38 °C). There are 76 days of 90+ °F highs annually. On average
column14: 96 °F (36 °C) is the highest temperature recorded each summer. Late summer brings an increased threat of tropical storms and hurricanes
column15: though landfalls are rare. Several major hurricanes have impacted Stuart since 1900
column16: with Hurricane David in 1979 and hurricanes Frances and Jeanne caused moderate damage to the area in 2004.Winter (November through April) or the dry season brings much cooler and drier air masses
column17: and humidity and dew points fall considerably. Winters can become quite dry
column18: and by late winter (March) there is often high fire danger and even residential water use restriction. Average daytime highs in the winter/dry season are from 73 °F (23 °C) to 77 °F (25 °C)
column19: though occasional strong cold fronts bring brief rainfall followed by cooler temperatures
column20: with highs in the 50s °F for a few days each winter. Low temperatures fall rarely fall below 40 °F (4 °C)
column21: and most winters are frost-free. The first cold front of the season usually occurs in October or November
column22: when the first low below 60 °F (16 °C) usually occurs. Though weather during this time is generally more mild
column23: mid winter highs can still hit 80 °F (27 °C) or higher on occasion.
